root.text:
Hey guys - my name is Aravind and I am the founder of <https://www.dev.goated.com/> - a sports trading exchange that is launching soon. Our api docs are here: <https://api.dev.goated.com/swagger-ui/> and we have built an sdk here: <https://docs.goated.com>.

I love what the community have done here with *betfairlightweight* and would love to get a similar high quality sdk for Goated so that existing betfair traders can also connect to Goated easily. Are there people here who might be exited in working with me on this?

elements.text: Hey guys - my name is Aravind and I am the founder of
- a sports trading exchange that is launching soon. Our api docs are here:
and we have built an sdk here:

.

I love what the community have done here with
betfairlightweight
and would love to get a similar high quality sdk for Goated so that existing betfair traders can also connect to Goated easily. Are there people here who might be exited in working with me on this?

text: Also, we won't have fiat rails and it will be exclusively deposit and withdrawals of crypto stable-coins. Is that a major blocker for people? If you have any feedback - feel free to dm me!

elements.text: Also, we won't have fiat rails and it will be exclusively deposit and withdrawals of crypto stable-coins. Is that a major blocker for people? If you have any feedback - feel free to dm me!

text:
Thanks for the reply <@U04SRDB8FKJ> but I don't think that addresses the question. As I said we see a lot of proposed exchanges and it's all very clever stuff but most only have a plans to attract pros but not actual customers.  Betfair have a high public awareness and the might of Paddy Power's advertising budget but still struggle so what makes you different? I'm obviously disinclined to invest my time in something and find the only people there are us, and most we see only seem to have plans to fund raise and sell up rather than anything approaching an actual sustainable business.   

That might seem a little more pointed than questions about fees and perks, but I'm sure these are questions your investors have asked, unless of course they're looking for a quick return rather than being involved in a long term business.

elements.text: Thanks for the reply

but I don't think that addresses the question. As I said we see a lot of proposed exchanges and it's all very clever stuff but most only have a plans to attract pros but not actual customers. I'm obviously disinclined to invest my time in something and find the only people there are us, and most we see only seem to have plans to fund raise and sell up rather than anything approaching an actual sustainable business.   

That might seem a little more pointed than questions about fees and perks, but I'm sure these are questions your investors have asked, unless of course they're looking for a quick return rather than being involved in a long term business.

text:
Have to agree with <@UEA14GBRR>. Kudos to you for doing this and for the quality of your implementation and documentation. But while the tech side looks great, I'm not seeing the long-term business rationale and without that, there's no incentive for me to invest time learning the ins and outs of a new platform.

I don't see a USP that would attract recreational bettors, or anything in your answers that suggests that attracting them is being considered. Being an exchange version of another platform who themselves don't seem to have a USP, is a bit underwhelming.

On the crypto point, I would see bypassing conventional banking deposits as a limiting factor and certainly not a USP?

elements.text: Have to agree with

. Kudos to you for doing this and for the quality of your implementation and documentation. But while the tech side looks great, I'm not seeing the long-term business rationale and without that, there's no incentive for me to invest time learning the ins and outs of a new platform.

I don't see a USP that would attract recreational bettors, or anything in your answers that suggests that attracting them is being considered. Being an exchange version of another platform who themselves don't seem to have a USP, is a bit underwhelming.

On the crypto point, I would see bypassing conventional banking deposits as a limiting factor and certainly not a USP?

text: If it was crypto deposits with zero annoying KYC I would not see that as a problem. But the lack of a diversified eco system of users would be.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon

text:
I agree about the crypto Peter. I don't actually know anyone who uses it for day to day transactions and if anything I just hear idioligical opposition and mistrust.  

The tech isn't the difficult part of setting up an exchange it's understanding how you'll become the name people think of when they want to place a bet. Taking a leaf from the bingo playbook, betting needs a compelling reason to "play" because the over complicated exchange model offering value nobody cares about is unlikely to take much business from tradional operators.  

I'm genuinely trying to be constructive and not just critical, I just feel without a novel and compelling customer offering that sells itself, the advertising budget alone to gain traction will be an obstacle.

elements.text:
I agree about the crypto Peter. I don't actually know anyone who uses it for day to day transactions and if anything I just hear idioligical opposition and mistrust.  

The tech isn't the difficult part of setting up an exchange it's understanding how you'll become the name people think of when they want to place a bet. Taking a leaf from the bingo playbook, betting needs a compelling reason to "play" because the over complicated exchange model offering value nobody cares about is unlikely to take much business from tradional operators.  

I'm genuinely trying to be constructive and not just critical, I just feel without a novel and compelling customer offering that sells itself, the advertising budget alone to gain traction will be an obstacle.

text: Crypto will be a blocker for a lot of people because of the additional tax implications. Currently in UK gambling profit is not taxed, but all crypto transactions are taxable. Not sure I would make use of such an exchange unless something drastic happens like the upcoming government white paper implementing SCV or ludicrous deposit restrictions (or something else that significantly impacts the gambling sector).

elements.text: Crypto will be a blocker for a lot of people because of the additional tax implications. Currently in UK gambling profit is not taxed, but all crypto transactions are taxable. Not sure I would make use of such an exchange unless something drastic happens like the upcoming government white paper implementing SCV or ludicrous deposit restrictions (or something else that significantly impacts the gambling sector).

text: Also, most crypto people are well aware that crypto influencers will happily shill shitcoins or anything else if paid enough to do so.

elements.text: Also, most crypto people are well aware that crypto influencers will happily shill shitcoins or anything else if paid enough to do so.

text:
I believe it will not be taxable (have spoken to an accountant but can get a more thorough tax opinion).

Gains from crypto investments are taxable in the UK but that is different to betting in USDC and winning USDC as part of that bet would be taxable.

(Will confirm these if this is still a worry btw).

(Will confirm these if this is still a worry btw).

text: Many of us rememeber when we paid 9% betting tax in the UK and you could choose for that to be on the stake or the winnings. A precident that even taxed losers isn't too hard to imagine being reinstated on profits, especially as our job is seen more and more as a profession rather than a lucrative sideline.

elements.text: Many of us rememeber when we paid 9% betting tax in the UK and you could choose for that to be on the stake or the winnings. A precident that even taxed losers isn't too hard to imagine being reinstated on profits, especially as our job is seen more and more as a profession rather than a lucrative sideline.

text:
Another factor to consider for anyone profitable is the fees associated with the fiat on and off ramps. Fees to buy USDC, then more fees to convert winnings back to fiat afterwards (assuming profits are made). This will also add another layer of KYC for those who do not currently dabble in crypto. Also, even if everything ends up not being taxable, records will need to be kept so that you can prove to the taxman that 50K from coinbase is gambling profit and NOT capital gains from trading shitcoins.

Don't get me wrong, I wish you success and some healthy exchange competition with quality API would be welcome. I'm just voicing concerns that new UK customers may not even be aware of.

If I were a purely recreational punter with no prior experience with crypto transactions then I really couldn't see myself using this unless UK government does something that means it is my only option.

elements.text:
Another factor to consider for anyone profitable is the fees associated with the fiat on and off ramps. Fees to buy USDC, then more fees to convert winnings back to fiat afterwards (assuming profits are made). This will also add another layer of KYC for those who do not currently dabble in crypto. Also, even if everything ends up not being taxable, records will need to be kept so that you can prove to the taxman that 50K from coinbase is gambling profit and NOT capital gains from trading shitcoins.

Don't get me wrong, I wish you success and some healthy exchange competition with quality API would be welcome. I'm just voicing concerns that new UK customers may not even be aware of.

If I were a purely recreational punter with no prior experience with crypto transactions then I really couldn't see myself using this unless UK government does something that means it is my only option.

text:
Poor old <@U04SRDB8FKJ>. He just wanted to solicit a bit of support and ended up with a phorensic investigation into the more undesirable possible effects of crypto in general. :thinking_face:

Back to the topic, if you aren't first to market then getting a foothold is harder than giving a few influences bags full of tenners. The next guy to come along will give them 20s and you're yesterday's news.     I would just love someone to say they've got a £50m advertising budget for a killer product and there's sponsoring the Grand National, who wants to be part of that.

This is the frustrating thing though because any legislation will be implemented by people who probably know jack shit about betting and will fail to see the subtle differences between exchange and bookmaker business models. text: It's at the operators discretion and triggered by deposits. Best advice I have to give is to contact Betfair or bookies with details of how you plan to operate. Even if you don't get a reply, planned behaviour can't be seen as additive or troublesome. Betfair obviously don't want to loose customers so work with them to justify your case before not after it's an issue.

text:
the documentation and technology is nice. The bottom line is that to exist as a p2p exchange with the sole USP being crypto-based deposits just sends the value to near-zero. For no other reason that you appear to want to operate in legal-waters. In the anecdotal venn-diagram of bettors, those who want a viable exchange are betting where liquidity is greatest; Betfair. Those who want to use crypto don't want any KYC.

I'm not sure the middle-ground, being a licenced operator (and therefore lawfully compliant to enforce KYC) is sufficient enough to mimic the massive success of <http://stake.com|stake.com>

Whomever successfully turns their back on the regulator and adopts a fair and honest -- but crucially close-to-anonymous exchange gets all the sweets.

text:
Yeah if you are UK based then KYC is unavoidable for crypto now (unless you have no need of a fiat off ramp). I think in the early days of crypto when people were mining it themselves and using it to pay for stuff on silk road you'd get people who'd run a mile from KYC. But these days if you are a UK customer you are KYC at all the main centralised exchanges.

The only reason I would want to use crypto at a betting exchange would be if it was a purely decentralised exchange OR if all fiat methods were no longer available. And with the former, I can't see a DEX being any good for anyone who wants to bet on the 20:30 at Wolverhampton in the middle of winter - it would only be viable for big stuff like superbowl or world cup. This was the kind of prediction market that Augur was meant to be but I've no idea if its still going.

elements.text:
Yeah if you are UK based then KYC is unavoidable for crypto now (unless you have no need of a fiat off ramp). I think in the early days of crypto when people were mining it themselves and using it to pay for stuff on silk road you'd get people who'd run a mile from KYC. But these days if you are a UK customer you are KYC at all the main centralised exchanges.

The only reason I would want to use crypto at a betting exchange would be if it was a purely decentralised exchange OR if all fiat methods were no longer available. And with the former, I can't see a DEX being any good for anyone who wants to bet on the 20:30 at Wolverhampton in the middle of winter - it would only be viable for big stuff like superbowl or world cup. This was the kind of prediction market that Augur was meant to be but I've no idea if its still going.

Some regs are there to protect and some hinder, you can't have it both ways. Opt out of 'the system' and you opt out of legal recourse if they go bust or vanish.

text:
of course <http://stake.com|stake.com> have KYC onsite. However, in the regions powering their almighty growth it is non-existent/not enforced.

The UK is not an attractive market for anyone given the draconian measures in place here.

Re: other crypto-exchanges having KYC too. Of course, they are legally required to. It's also why they will be bound to minimal growth.

If betfair accept crypto at any point, it's game over right? Just like the other crypto sites appearing it seems like an odd not-so-USP to build an entire business on.

text: I don't think betfair will accept crypto - they are too big and haven't innovated in a meaningful way in last decade. Adding crypto won't be in their dna. Also, curious to know why you say <http://stake.com|stake.com> doesn't have kyc in regions powering their growth. What regions are these?  One big advantage of crypto rails for an exchange is global liquidity where someone from two different countries can trade against each other (just like crypto exchanges).

text: Compared with other exchanges Betfair is doing well I'd say. Yeah they have outages and when they do it is a PITA, but they have the stream API now whereas Betdaq are still running that clunky old SOAP atrocity. As for smarkets and matchbook, I've heard they ban winners because they trade their own markets so they are not even an option for most people. That last sentence could be untrue, but this is definitely the impression I get from talking to others.
